text: For those of you who manage freelancers, contractors and in-house team members: I’m curious to hear what content producer roles are on your team and what level of output you expect (e.g. # of completed articles/month) for different experience levels and areas of focus.

elements.text: For those of you who manage freelancers, contractors and in-house team members: I’m curious to hear what content producer roles are on your team and what level of output you expect (e.g. # of completed articles/month) for different experience levels and areas of focus.

text:
We've always worked backward from the expectation that one full-time human can publish two posts per week (to our standard). That's based on a lot of experience writing (myself and those before me).

Basically, we see about 12 hours as the floor for writing a post, though it could easily take 16 or more hours.

(In practice, a full-time author for us writes one post and sources/edits one post from outside the company each week.)

So, if we decide that someone needs to spend X% of their time doing something other than writing/editing, we're bringing someone on with output expectations (and compensation) based on that standard of ~14 hrs per post.

I _could_ see this being a much trickier issue if the editorial standard were flexible, if the output targets were wholly inflexible, or if you were producing a new type of content.

text: <@UJDPMTREY> I’m looking to hone a similar kind of estimation for my team so this is incredibly helpful. When your team is writing their own content, does that process typically include interviewing outside sources or are those pieces based on research and written solo? (Basically--what level of collaboration and managing non-writing work goes into the piece? The value + time cost of when we interview or collaborate with external experts has been high on my mind lately.)

elements.text: I’m looking to hone a similar kind of estimation for my team so this is incredibly helpful. When your team is writing their own content, does that process typically include interviewing outside sources or are those pieces based on research and written solo? (Basically--what level of collaboration and managing non-writing work goes into the piece? The value + time cost of when we interview or collaborate with external experts has been high on my mind lately.)

text:
An ideal CXL blog post is (1) an exhaustive set of best practices (2) sprinkled with nuance and counterexamples from expert practitioners. We don't hit that mark every time, but that's been the MO for most of the blog's existence.

If I'm sticking with (semi)hypothetical ideals, a writer is sourcing the next round of interview candidates at the same time they're organizing the most recent batch of responses _and_ polishing a final draft.

Our start-up-y-ness usually tempers that vision. I have tried to source material for _multiple_ posts via a single interview but haven't had tons of success with that (especially if I'm gathering info via email or a survey).

The best and cheapest hack I know of is to pull expert quotes from other places---webinars, blog posts, social media, etc.

(The most wasteful thing I see is people bothering experts to give them "their top tip" on XYZ, which they already could've found a million places online. Experts are there to tell you things you don't already know or to call out best practices as insufficient, unrealistic, or flat-out wrong.)

But I do love a good in-person interview. The correlation between the number of people I _talk to_ for a post and the quality/performance of that post is strong.

text: It sounds like you have a really clear vision for your content and some great processes. I feel you on the ideal vs reality! Thanks so much for sharing, this is really helpful insight.

elements.text: It sounds like you have a really clear vision for your content and some great processes. I feel you on the ideal vs reality! Thanks so much for sharing, this is really helpful insight.

text: I have a business that enlists subject matter experts (as opposed to freelance/pro writers) to create content in their area of expertise.  It's an interesting dynamic, since (I think) everyone writing is doing it as a side hustle, which means that the business has comparably little leverage to try to prod anyone to commit to and deliver a specific cadence or volume.

elements.text: I have a business that enlists subject matter experts (as opposed to freelance/pro writers) to create content in their area of expertise.  It's an interesting dynamic, since (I think) everyone writing is doing it as a side hustle, which means that the business has comparably little leverage to try to prod anyone to commit to and deliver a specific cadence or volume.

text: More prolific authors do maybe 2-3 blog posts in a week as part of their side hustle (1,200 - 1,500 words), while others might just do one post per month or two.

elements.text: More prolific authors do maybe 2-3 blog posts in a week as part of their side hustle (1,200 - 1,500 words), while others might just do one post per month or two.

text: But we also have dedicated folks to help with editorial and a separate, different quality assurance pass, so the authors aren't tasked with end-to-end ownership of the deliverable.

elements.text: But we also have dedicated folks to help with editorial and a separate, different quality assurance pass, so the authors aren't tasked with end-to-end ownership of the deliverable.

text: That’s a cool model <@U017XD7H4P7> and it definitely helps when you have separate support for the planning, project management, editing etc. Do your writers pitch you ideas or is your team always creating and assigning specific briefs based on expertise?

elements.text: That’s a cool model

and it definitely helps when you have separate support for the planning, project management, editing etc. Do your writers pitch you ideas or is your team always creating and assigning specific briefs based on expertise?

text:
<@URB31QKM4> At Animalz output expectation stays pretty consistent as far as actual articles (2 articles/week across the board). What changes as Content Managers level up is the amount of autonomy they're expected to operate with. We have 9 levels overall - L1-L3, you're getting a lot of direction from your Strategist (manager) on calendar management, pitches, reporting, approaches to individual articles. L4-L6, you take point but get input from your strategist when you need it - L7 and up, you run the show and maybe get some backup from a Strategist when things get really complicated.

We also have a dedicated team for research, so CMs across the board can get help on that front (as long as they fill out a brief and get it on the research calendar in a timely manner :wink:)

text:
<@UJ48Q1HAP> That is really interesting, thank you! We have career bands at Sprout, but they are pretty wide and I’ve actually been thinking about adding levels within them (at minimum Role vs. Senior Role, but the idea of 3 levels per band makes sense too).

Can you tell me a little more about the research team and the depth of what’s provided to writers? E.g. is that essentially fleshing out a hefty brief with competing articles, third party data, etc. or is it more like conducting industry interviews, developing unique research/data, etc? Feel free to DM if it feels like it’s veering off topic!

text: Basically, I’ve realized that two of my direct reports are doing everything in this thread as well as working on cross-functional projects as planners and strategists, so I need to adjust my writing output expectations. But I’d like to develop a clear, shared set of expectations that can help me understand our team-wide capacity, as well as guide individual growth and performance conversations. Really appreciate the input so far!

elements.text: Basically, I’ve realized that two of my direct reports are doing everything in this thread as well as working on cross-functional projects as planners and strategists, so I need to adjust my writing output expectations. But I’d like to develop a clear, shared set of expectations that can help me understand our team-wide capacity, as well as guide individual growth and performance conversations. Really appreciate the input so far!

text: <@URB31QKM4> we create the briefs for the authors based on KPIs and a strategy plan with our clients.  But we have so many authors and produce such a high volume of content that assignment wouldn't scale, so we rely on vetted authors to volunteer/self-select, based on their backgrounds and expertise related to the topics.

elements.text: we create the briefs for the authors based on KPIs and a strategy plan with our clients.  But we have so many authors and produce such a high volume of content that assignment wouldn't scale, so we rely on vetted authors to volunteer/self-select, based on their backgrounds and expertise related to the topics.
